children.subject: ^ Agree, there is almost no reason to do DS + EECS imo

Yeah,

maybe doing an applied math if you want to take some math classes

or double another major in Engineering if you have the time.

If you are already EECS, what would be the great benefit of also doing a DS major? The EECS/CS degrees and the DS degree aren't really that different in terms of classes that could potentially fulfill both majors, and with EECS you have a greater chance of getting into the CS classes DS majors would also use for their own degree requirements. I'm not sure declaring DS would help you get into any classes for which you don't already have enrollment priority, so why not just take those courses if you are interested? It may be nice to have EECS+DS in your degree, but is it worth having to take all of the L&S breadths just for that? If you simply did the DS minor, you might be able to take all of the DS-related classes you wouldn't have taken as an EECS major, and you wouldn't have to do any L&S college requirements, which saves you at least a couple semesters worth of classes... And for grad school, if you wanted to do some DS program, I don't think you would be at all disadvantaged if your undergrad major was EECS

history.content: Are we allowed to declare a double major in Data Science if we are currently EECS? Would this recquire completing all the L&S breadth requirements too? I have also heard that there are certain rules about overlapping major classes, but can't seem to find info on this anywhere. Thanks!
history.subject: Double major EECS + DS?
